Award.AwardTitle: University of Minnesota Materials Research Science and Engineering Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) at the University of Minnesota (UMN) unites established senior and promising junior faculty from six departments and two other universities in a multidisciplinary program to address fundamental issues spanning a broad spectrum of materials research. The research mission of the Center is founded upon four Interdisciplinary Research Groups (IRGs):
IRG-1: Engineered Multiblock Polymers implements powerful synthesis and processing strategies for advanced materials based on self-assembly of multiblock copolymers. These new materials may be used for controlled porosity membranes and drug delivery.
IRG-2: Organic Optoelectronic Interfaces is developing a comprehensive understanding of structure-property relationships in a new generation of electronic materials.
IRG-3: Magnetic Heterostructures explores spin transport, spin transfer torque, and novel highly polarized materials in precisely engineered heterostructures. This may lead to new magnetic memory devices and new paradigms in computation.
IRG-4: Nanoparticle-based Materials is creating environmentally benign nanoparticle-based materials for applications in luminescence and photovoltaics.

The UMN MRSEC manages an extensive program in education and career development. Center research activities are integrated with educational programs, providing interdisciplinary training of students and postdocs. The summer research program features four distinct efforts, two of which, Faculty-Student Teams; Native American Fellowships, target Tribal Colleges. The Research Experiences for Undergraduates and Research Experiences for Teachers programs also attract a significant population of female and underrepresented minority undergraduates to the University.

MRSEC faculty and student participate in numerous K-12 outreach activities that include a program of summer camps for high school students and working with the Science Museum of Minnesota in developing exhibits, providing demonstrations, and staffing booths.

The MRSEC is bolstered by a broad complement of over 35 companies that contribute directly to IRG research through intellectual, technological, and financial support in a collaborative and pre-competitive environment through the Industrial Partnership for Research in Interfacial and Materials Engineering (IPRIME) and the Center for Micromagnetics and Information Technologies (MINT). International research collaborations and student exchanges are pursued with leading research labs in Asia and Europe. The UMN MRSEC benefits from an extensive suite of materials synthesis, characterization and computational facilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Minnesota Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) united 34 established senior and promising junior faculty from eight departments in an interlocking but multidisciplinary program. Our intellectual focus was organized around four Interdisciplinary Research Groups that collectively addressed the meticulous control of composition, structure, and properties in advanced materials. These include IRG-1: Engineered Multiblock Polymers; IRG-2: Organic Optoelectronic Interfaces; IRG-3: Magnetic Heterostructures; IRG-4: Nanoparticle-Based Materials. IRG-1 has implemented powerful synthesis and processing strategies for advanced macromolecular materials based on self-assembly of multiblock copolymers. IRG-2 has developed a comprehensive understanding of structure-property relationships for a new generation of electronic materials. IRG-3 has explored spin transport, spin transfer torque, and novel highly polarized materials in precisely engineered heterostructures. IRG-4 has created environmentally benign nanoparticle-based materials for applications in luminescence and photovoltaics. Overall, this award has led to more than 450 publications, with a further 330 that used the Shared Facilities; a total of 9 patents have been awarded, 2 licensed, and 25 are pending. During the course of the award, 137 graduate students earned PhD degrees with MRSEC support, and a further 46 postdoctoral fellows completed their training.  

      Our summer research programs for undergraduates have involved 117 summer students and 25 K-12 teachers. Notably, 47% of these undergraduates have been members of underrepresented groups, and 45% have been female. The summer programs encompassed summer research fellowships for Faculty-Student teams from four-year and two-year colleges, and Tribal Colleges in the Upper Midwest, fellowships for individual Native American students, and Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU). The MRSEC partnered with the University of Texas-Pan American (UTPA) through a Partnership for Research and Education and Materials (PREM) Award, and UTPA students and faculty participated vigorously in the summer research program. In addition, seven UTPA faculty engaged in collaborative research with MRSEC faculty representing IRGs 1, 2, and 4. We have sponsored public demonstration shows (“Physics Force” and “Energy & U”) to over 100,000 K-12 students. The Shared Experimental Facilities in a typical year serve over 500 distinct users from 30 UMN departments, as well as 50 companies and over 20 other academic institutions. The UMN MRSEC continued its pioneering participation in the Materials Research Facilities Network, which enabled financial awards for travel and facility usage to 54 research groups, representing 35 academic institutions nationwide, to enable use of advanced characterization equipment at the University of Minnesota. Through the Industrial Partnership for Research in Interfacial and Materials Engineering (IPRIME), the UMN MRSEC interacted with a broad complement of more than 30 companies that make direct financial contributions to the research programs associated with the Center. IPRIME member companies also participated in collaborative research by sending visiting industrial fellows to UMN labs. This partnership introduced valuable industrial perspectives that strengthen MRSEC programs and enhanced the education of Center students. These interactions, together with education initiatives, linked traditionally segregated segments of the profession and society to materials research and significantly expanded the impact of the Center beyond the UMN.
